headline: Homestyle Potato Chips
description: Homemade potato chips? Absolutely! They're golden, crispy, and delicious, and they smell heavenly. Plus you can use any oil and amount of salt you like.

video.description: See how to make crispy homemade potato chips.
video.name: Homestyle Potato Chips

name: Homestyle Potato Chips
recipeIngredient: 4 medium potatoes, peeled and sliced paper-thin
3 tablespoons salt, plus more to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Transfer potato slices to a large bowl of cold water as you slice them.
Drain slices and rinse under cold water. Refill the bowl with water, add 3 tablespoons salt, and put slices back in the bowl. Let potatoes soak in the salty water for at least 30 minutes.
Drain and rinse slices again. Pat dry.
Heat oil in a deep-fryer to 365 degrees F (185 degrees C).
Working in small batches, fry potato slices until golden. Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels. Continue until all of the slices are fried.
Season potato chips with additional salt if desired.

review.reviewBody: I Just would like to say Potato chips cost 7.00 for a small bag . A bag of potatoes cost 2.50. What do you think? I Loved Making them even better with my lunch the next day!! I give this 5 stars.
Just delicious. I didn't make any changes.

This is the best homemade chip recipe! I use a mandolin to slice the potatoes, that way they are the same and cook evenly. When done, I give them a small sprinkle of sea salt. Thank you for this recipe!!

I don't mind them hand cut a little thicker, but they do turn out more tender rather than crispy. If you have a mandolin slicer, they are fantastic for super thin sliced anything .... just watch your fingers! The brining makes these very flavourful.
I have tried to make homemade potato chips for over 20 years with no success. Until I found this recipe. So easy and so good.
I used a potato peeler to make thin slices.
Love the recipe. Made my own BBQ seasoning. Better than store bought.
I just need to buy different seasonings now! (Sour cream & onion, bbq, etc...)

5 stars for simplicity! My food processor died so I had to use the hand grater. One less thumb knuckle later... we have chips! :D Also, I just used an old pot (the one I use for chili) with a small bottle of virgin olive oil. Batches consisted of enough chips to cover 2 paper towels. 7 minutes per batch. Since this was a first time for me, I tested and noted times. Almost forgot - I had no way of measuring temperature either. Yes, I live in the past. I've just come to the future to post this review. Just let oil heat on med/high for about 5 min. Enjoy!

Came out great! Not sure if others said this but I just used a potato peeler to cut the chips. About as thin as you can get. Came out looking like store-bought only they tasted a thousand times better. Only challenge was not eating them all before serving them. I only ate about half which I thought was pretty impressive really.

A Disaster.
I am not a novice in the kitchen. I followed the directions to the letter. By the time they became crispy enough to pass for what one would call a 'potato chip' .. they were far too dark to serve.
There may be a good method out there somewhere.. This ain't it.

Awesome recipe! Super easy too. I had the idea to look up how to make chips after accidentally slicing way too much potato for dinner and trying to figure out what else to do with the slices. This worked perfect.

I've never thought about putting salt in the water. I always wait until after they r fried and then sprinkle them with whatever homemade seasoning I have made. I can't say whether this made any difference or not? I will say though that I usually rinse and repeat, rinse and repeat, rinse and repeat in ice cold water! I don't want any starch in that water. yes they need to be sliced very thin like on the thinnest setting on your mandolin!
Followed recipe exact. Not too salty. The tip to make bbq chips w smoked paprika, garlic powder, salt, and sugar was INSANE!
Totally delicious and worth the bit of time and effort!
good but you gotta cut them mad thin

Use a mandolin!!! These are just as delicious the next day. I followed the directions and may never buy potato chips again! They were delicious even after two days in a zip lock on the counter! And took only 20 minutes hands on work to slice and fry (4 batches). Thank you!

Used russet potatos that I hand sliced and soaked them in half vinegar half water for about an hour. Vinegar flavor was subtle so I’m sure if I soaked them longer it would’ve been stronger. Seasoned some with salt and some with Cajun seasoning. Came out amazing and the kids loved them too. The whole family loved them actually! You really can’t go wrong with these, saves you a lot on chips.
This is an amazing recipe and tastes miraculous, I definitely recommend this recipe.
Absolutely perfect I think. I made it for my children and they like it very much. They did not wait until I roast them. Thanks for such a good recipe.
Love these. I added BBQ rub to the chips after they came out of the oil. Delicious BBQ chips they kids live them!!!
Not bad chips are pretty basic when it comes to cooking. The one review just seems petty they can't cut the potato thin so they left a bad review.

Hallelujah! Fried potato chips from the comforts of home. No need to go out to the sporting clubs or sandwich shops for these crunchy delights. I topped off my batch with a smattering of delicious Kerry Gold Pure Irish Butter. Kerry Gold simply has no competition when it comes to consistent spreadability and smooth creamy finish. I may fry the things in the stuff for round two!

Perfect chips. I sliced them thin with a mandoline and then fried at 360. No need to even salt them as the salt solution provided enough seasoning. I will making these again. Not that great for my waistline, but so tasty!

I made these once last night, and again just a little while ago. My family and I LOVE these! They disappear faster than I can make them! Lol. I sprinkled some seasoned salt on them with black pepper. YUM!!!
I boiled the chips in vinegar first for flavour
Tasted great! I used cajun style seasoning salt instead. So yummy.

These chips came out great. I have a good mandalin so they were nice and thin and I added some vinegar to the final rinse to avoid potatoes going brown. I also spread them all out on a towel to dry them out a bit for about 30 minutes on a hot day. Next time I will add vinegar and salt to the final rinse and not rinse after that
They turned out perfect! Everyone kept coming back for more!
Turned out good for my first time.
This recipe was perfect. It was my first time making home-made potato chips and my family loved them! I've made them twice now, and will be making more this weekend!
Really good, really easy! We love them.

I hand sliced the potatoes very thin with a filet knife, skins on (I prefer them this way) and rinsed until the water was clear then soaked them in cold water, no salt, for a few hours. Patted them dry on paper towels before frying so as to not have any oil popping. I used peanut oil. I also tossed them in a bowl while sprinkling salt on afterwards, while they were still hot.

This is the best basic potato chip recipe. I did make some some changes as most people do. I sliced them on my cheap mandolin on the thinnest setting, perfect by my standards for chips. I soaked them in a sugar/hottest tap water mix for a good 10 minutes, drained and rinsed. Then returned to a ice cold salt water bath for 30 minutes. Drain, rinse, and dry thoroughly. Fry as instructed, however, remove to a cooling rack so they don't sit in the oil dripping off. After all are done, fry once more for a minute or so for the super extra crispy.
Chips turned out great. Cooking time is 5-7 minutes depending on how crowded your fryer is. The chips will quit bubbling, which is a good sign that all of the water has been cooked out as steam.
I added All Purpose Greek Seasoning instead of salt very good :)
Didn't change a thing, turned out great. A mandolin helps out a ton.
OMG! I had no idea it was just that easy!!! and stupid yummy!!!!.....:)
I added my own seasoning to them

I soaked according to directions. I also pulled a handful off to the side and soaked in vinegar (according to reviewers). I used a mandolin and played with 2 different thicknesses... (paper thin and thin) . just crisp them up according to directions. 

as far as playing in flavors, I haven't really tried. but the possibilities are endless.... like taking that powdered marinade meat rub, or taking a spray bottle of vinegar. 

i can totally see making these for fish and chips. 

btw, ranch chips? what about sprinkling that popcorn seasoning on them???
Came out great! I will definitely make them again. It did take a little longer to fry them since we like chips golden brown. Next time i will sprinkle with black pepper too.
I left the skin on and sprinkled it with some slap yo momma seasoning and it was really good!!
my family loves them... i mix salt and rosemary together, to sprinkle over mine... very delicious
This recipe was very easy to make, kept it exact as stated here. I'll definitely make this again
Because I make them
Just tried this need a slicer to thick by hand lol. Def going to try the vinegar soak for chips next time along with my fries
tasty and way less expensive than store bought. Sprinkle Old Bay to give the a Maryland flavor.
My husband loves these and has me make them for him all the time! A potato slicer is a must to get the slices thin.
Thin is good, watch them closely though!! I used #2 on my mandolin and the chips are just the right thickness!
Perfect! Be sure of paper thin size...as thin as possible. Crispy & delicious!

Easy recipe. I used the food processor to ensure consistent thickness of the slices.
They were gone in minutes!
Oh very yummy. I ate the first three batches by myself. It was very easy to make your own potato chips!
way way too salty I recommend cutting back the salt significantly. otherwise they fried up nicely

Made these per recipe & they are fantastic. Frying took about 5-6 min per batch & I made sure to check oil temp before adding a new batch. It's been 3 days (stored in brown paper bag on counter) & they are still crispy & fresh!
When each batch was finished cooking, I used Seasoned Salt and it tasted amazing, I also used some garlic salt on another batch and it also tasted great. Love these!

I used peanut oil and a mandolin to slice the potatoes extra thin and soaked in cold water 20 minutes and then dried well. This made wonderful chips which after pulling out of the oil and allowing the oil to drip off onto a paper towel I sprinkled salt and a cajun spice mix that I made on top. Wonderful home made chips, everyone enjoyed them. There was not one left.

These chips turned out awesome. I only had small red potatoes but they worked amazing for this recipe. I let them soak in warm salt water for 1 hour before rinsing them, and dried them out for half an hour. They turned out super crisp, and I made them real thin with my food processor which is a MAJOR plus. Overall, this is one of the best recipes for potato chips I have ever made, and my family sure seemed to enjoy them too!
This worked well and tasted great. The toughest thing is getting the potatoes slicedthin and evenly. Will definitely do it again.
I've never made homestyle chips before, but I thought these turned out pretty awesome! Plus any excuse to break out the mandolin to cut some waffle chips is a bonus.
i ddnt make any changes, they turned out very good, I will be making this again
Followed the recipe as given, it came out soooo tasty. Thanks !!!

These are wonderful. I didn't change anything, but I did soak them longer because my husband was delayed so I ended up soaking them for 2 hours. Mine were so crispy, I have never made homemade chips that crunchy before, Awesome! I saw some remarks about other peoples not being crispy enough, my suggestion would be take your time slicing the potatoes, don't rush it, slowly slice them as thin as possible, so thin you can almost see though it. This makes them perfectly crispy in the end. Enjoy! We did !
These were delicious. I seasoned with garlic salt and lowreys seasoning. I used vegetable oil and sliced by potato super thin with an awesome knife I got from Sweden.

Awesome in its simplicity! I received an air fryer as a gift and have been testing it out for various potatoes. For this one, I used a mandolin to slice 3 white potatoes as thin as possible (I can't slice anything paper thin with a knife without losing a finger). I then soaked the slices in cold water. Not sure if it would have been better soaking them in hot water so that is an experiment for another time.

It takes some time and patience, but an easy way to get paper-thin slices is to just take your potato peeler and peel off little slices.

Also, I like throwing some cayenne pepper onto the chips after taking them out of the fryer
I used a mixture of purple, baby reds, and yellow gold potatoes. I used cavenders Greek seasoning and cooked these in my cast iron skillet. Beautiful, crunchy potato chips in less than 5 minutes.
Super easy. I just don't have the patience to wait for the soak part

Unfortunately the attachment on my food processor could not help with this so I had to cut very thin slices of poatoes. So, prep took a bit longer but not a problem. It only took about 5 minutes in the the deep fryer. After removing them from the fryer, drained, salted they were great fresh and warm. The consistency did not hold up when they cooled off. Maybe an error on my part. I would recommend this as a fast way to fry potatoes but not as chips. Thanks for sharing this recipe, it will make a great fast way to fry potatoes.

Turned out great, only one problem: I had trouble drying up the potatoes well, since the slices ended up really thin. What happened is the oil from the fryer started to burst out a bit, so had to do quite the cleanup. Otherwise, great results.
Yummy!

I don't have a fryer, so I used a deep fryer thermometer and a heavy sauce pan. I have one of those slicer dicer things and used the thin blade. I kept the oil at 350° and fried a few at a time until they were brown. . using a slotted spoon I transferred them onto a salted paper towel, then transferred them on a brown paper bag. this will keep them crispy. they are quite good! yummy!

I didn't have a problem getting them thin enough, they came out nice and crunchy. I Left the lid up on my deep fryer. You got to keep your eye on this like it's bacon. Doesn't take too much to burn them.
Fun thing to make with the kids on rainy days. Go to the popcorn section of your store and there are flavours like Sour Cream & Onion you can sprinkle on them. Home made flavoured chips YUM!
Great recipe simple I used a food processor and sea salt after so good!!
There good
I found this recipe for my son that's obsessed with potato chips and wanted to try making his own. He loves it.
Thanks you.

I've made these for years and they are always a hit. Some of the seasonings I've used have been malt vinegar, dill, and onion powder. My family also loves Johnny's seasoning salt and a bit of chili powder on them for a little cajun-like taste.
Excellent recipe...Use a mandolin slicer to slice the potatoes...Best little kitchen tool for slicing veggies paper thin...Peace
I use a frydaddy! Such an easy snack! I crave them!!!!!!

I made these for the first time tonight, July, 17, 2014. I was always afraid to try home made because I could never cut the potatoes thin enough. I have an inexpensive mandolin that is perfectly suited for thin slicing. Once this was done the rest is easy! My husband raved and said they were as good as Lays! I know he was being kind, but I will take that compliment any time. I finally got to try the last batch I made because I never brought them out to him!
Excellent! Never a chip left. I use my $15 handheld mandolin to slice (from Kohls).

I followed cmatlock's advice to use HOT water, because it made sense. And used a veggie peeler to make the slices. Came out PERFECT! (and this could be a problem...couldn't stop eating them...) also, I used grape seed oil for two reasons: it's a healthier fat & it has a very high burn point. I use it for all of my frying.
Thanks for the recipe!
These were awesome, i fried mines in a pan because i dont have a deep fryer. It was really good, my son loved them, they were nice and crispy.
I have not made them yet but I do love the ratings and I love the extra ideas people have done I am making some today Excited to try
loved it!!

This was my first time trying homemade chips, as well as using my new fryer! I also used potatoes that had started to "eye", and I had them in water for only about 20 minutes before towel drying them and frying. I also did not soak them in salt water, just tap water. I don't have a special tool for slicing them, so I used a potato peeler to make the slices. For us, this was the perfect consistency and chip size. I fried each batch for six minutes, and it was perfectly golden/brown. I put them onto a plate with a towel, and then salted them immediately. My whole family devoured them! My six year old daughter said that they were the best chips she'd ever eaten. Really great!
these were delicious!!!!Definitely a keeper

I just made these for the first time, and I kept it simple, but I wanted to pass on the technique that I used: I washed and removed eyes from 4 red potatoes, but did not peel them. Some of my taters were sprouting from their eyes already. I sliced them with my pampered chef mandoline slicer, so it only has the one thin slicing blade. I soaked the slices in cold water, changed the water several times, and the last soaking I added a hefty amount of salt. Rinsed them again, laid the slices on kitchen cloths/paper towels, and patted them dry.
I heated my 10-inch cast iron frying pan, added about 1/2 cup canola oil, and brought it up to heat (level 8 out of 10 on a gas stove). I added potato slices so they could float freely side-by-side, not stacked on top of each other. I found that using 2 long-tined dinner forks were perfect for moving them, turning them, and removing them to a waiting paper-toweled cookie sheet, where I sprinkled them with salt. They were delicious! 
The first bunch were probably undercooked, as I was afraid of burning them, but the later batches were crispy on the edges, barely soft in the middle, perfect! I will make these again! I wish I had some malt vinegar to sprinkle over them right now!
average.. maybe add some seasoning to them after.

I love these potato chips, butI can't have the salt. What can i use besides the salt!!
Good recipe!!

I don't have a deep fryer-I skimmed some reviews to see if anyone had made these without one & I didn't see one right off. So, I thought I might as well try... They turned out fine from the iron skillet, but it took FOREVER to fry them all! I should have cut the recipe in half! LOL!...Anyway, they tasted great! They did get soggy once cooled-I reheated them on a cookie sheet & they were crispier again.
need to slice them thinner than you think.
Great recipe. After frying i sprinkled with seasoning salt, garlic powder and parmesan cheese and they were fantastic.
excellent! my kids were shocked how good these were! will be making again
These came out well but too salty. I'll reduce the salt to 1 tablespoon next time I try.
These are fantastic! They came out perfect, not greasy. Nice and crisp. Will recommend this to anyone. Never have to buy another bag of chips!
Very good!

I just finished making a batch of these and wow, they are so good! I'm making them for my husband so I tried to use some self control while sampling them. It would be fun to experiment with different seasonings! I used the thick side of my cheese grater, they really were 'paper' thin and I think that's probably the best way to make them. Also, be sure to really dry your potatoes off before frying them...use a towel though, paper towel will stick to them (learned that the hard way). Delicious!
